dc:description:
*ODAD1*, also known as *CCDC114*, was first reported in relation to Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia in 2013 (PMIDs 23261302 and 23261303). It encodes a coiled-coil domain-containing protein that is an essential component of the outer dynein arm-docking complex required for the correct attachment of the ODA to the microtubule doublet (PMID: 35163670). Reported PCD phenotype in patients with *ODAD1* mutations includes decreased nasal nitric oxide, recurrent respiratory tract infections, neonatal respiratory distress, bronchiectasis, and/or situs abnormalities along with ultrastructural ODA defect (PMIDs 23261302 and 23261303). Milder phenotype has been linked to a partially functioning mutant protein which allowed for assembly of some ODAs and a significant level of ciliary activity (PMID: 35163670).
5 (frameshift and splice site) variants that have been reported in 6 probands carrying biallelic *ODAD1* mutations are included in this curation (PMIDs: 23261302, 23261303 and 35163670). A conserved haplotype is detected to lie in cis with the 853G>A variant, compatible with being a founder mutation (PMID: 23261303). Segregation analysis in multiple Volendam family members confirmed a consistent recessive pattern of inheritance (PMID: 23261303). Lack of infertility among affected family members is suggested to arise from genetic redundancy as CCDC63 could potentially replace CCDC114 function in sperm (PMID: 23261303).
Experimental evidence also supports this gene disease relationship. Expression analysis via RT-PCR reveals that *ODAD1* shows high expression in lung and testis (PMID: 23261302). Subcellular localization of ODAD1 protein confirmed its expression along the entire length of human cilia (PMID: 23261303). *ODAD1* mutant cilia showed abnormal ciliary motility comprising large areas of static cilia, with occasionally stiff cilia having a twitching or flickering movement that is slow, and ineffective for mucus transport across the epithelial surface (PMID: 23261303). ODAD1 expression in cultured human bronchial cells paralleled the time course of ciliary differentiation and DNAI1 expression which indicates a crucial role in ciliogenesis (PMID: 23261302). The Chlamydomonas orthologue of *ODAD1* (Oda1; Dcc2) has been shown to be a component of the outer dynein arm docking complex (ODA-DC) that is essential for the assembly of the ODA (PMID: 11907279). 

In summary, *ODAD1* is definitively associated with autosomal recessive Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia 20. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and diagnostic settings and has been upheld overtime.
This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on August 17, 2022 (SOP Version 9).

evidence.dc:description: The model organism can not fully recapitulate human phenotype. However, structural and functional alteration have been observed
In humans, primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD), seems most frequently to be caused by loss of the outer dynein arms
evidence.rdfs:label: Characterization of ODAD1 ortholog in Chlamydomonas

evidence.dc:description: ODAD1 mutant cilia compared to normal controls showed abnormal ciliary motility comprising large areas of static cilia, with occasionally 1–2 cilia having a twitching or flickering movement that was stiff, slow, and ineffective for mucus transport across the epithelial surface. This is consistent with findings in other PCD individuals lacking the ODAs
evidence.rdfs:label: High-speed video imaging of ODAD1 mutant cells

evidence.dc:description: Cross-section Analysis of ciliary ultrastructure by Electron Microscopy showed normal ciliary ultrastructure from healthy subject compared to absence of outer dynein arms  from UNC family 62 with biallelic mutations in ODAD1.
evidence.rdfs:label: Ciliary Ultrastructure by Electron Microscopy

evidence.dc:description: The experiment indicates a crucial role of ODAD1 during ciliogenesis in human airway cells. Abnormal ciliary structure and function results in various PCD phenotypes in ODAD1 mutant patients (recurrent respiratory tract infection, otitis media, etc)
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression pattern of ODAD1 during ciliogenesis

evidence.dc:description: Expression analysis via RT-PCR reveals that CCDC114 shows a similar pattern of expression (e.g., high in lung and testis) as DNAI1, mutations in which cause PCD with ciliary ODA defects
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression Analysis of ODAD1 via Reverse-Transcriptase PCR

evidence.dc:description: In controls, CCDC114 antisera decorates the full length of the cilia (Figure 3B), suggesting that its putative role in tethering of outer dynein arms is required along the entire axoneme.
evidence.rdfs:label: Protein localization of ODAD1 by IF in ciliated epithelium

evidence.dc:description: c.742G>A substitution affects the final G nucleotide of ODAD1 exon7, one of the consensus splice donor bases essential to the mRNA splicing machinery. This base change is therefore predicted to cause a frameshift in the ODAD1 protein resulting from loss of the conserved donor splice site which was further confirmed by RT-PCR. Downscoring for homozygosity and being an individual of a large multigeneration family originating from ancestral marriage.

A larger RT-PCR product size was amplified from the patient, compared to controls . Sequence analysis revealed an intronic insertion of 79 basepairs after the end of exon 7, shifting the protein reading frame and introducing a novel nonsense codon 52 residues downstream (p.Ala248Thrfs52*).

evidence.rdfs:label: Onoufriadis_PCD-01 III:8
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Neonatal pneumonia, situs solitus, serous otitis media, and chronic wet cough.

evidence.dc:description: A conserved haplotype lies in cis with the c.742G>A mutation, compatible with being a founder mutation. We already scored the Volendam proband homozygous for the c.742G>A mutation PMID 23261303.

The exonic splice-site mutation c.742G>A  yielded two mutant transcripts,
both resulting in premature translation termination signals (Table 2, Figure S2). Using a different downstream primer set revealed another splicing defect on the same mutant allele, indicating impairment of splicing distal to the mutation, (Table 2, Figure S3). The aberrant splicing that is three exons downstream from c.742G>A could not compensate for the upstream frameshift, as the upstream insertions lead to termination codons before the inclusion of intron 10.

The variant was detected in trans with an established pathogenic variant for an AR disease in 2 affected sisters with classical PCD phenotype. c.1050del (p.His350fs) is a 1 bp deletion that result in a frameshift and premature termination (His313GlnfsTer14). gnomAD Maximum MAF in Ashkenazi Jewish is 0.0003968
Maximum MAF in Ashkenazi Jewish 0.0003968

evidence.rdfs:label: Knowles_1107
evidence.detectionMethod: mutations in the two genes (DNAH5 [MIM 603335]; DNAI1 [MIM 604366]) most frequently associated with ODA defects  had been excluded by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: situs solitus, ODA ciliary ultrastructural defect

evidence.dc:description: c.1502+5G>A is a splice mutation in IVS14 of ODAD1 resulted in the skipping of exon 14 and the introduction of a premature translation codon (pSer469Argfs*7). Retaining partial ciliary function  in the presence of a truncated ODAD1 protein able to incorporate into the ciliary axoneme supports ODAD1 structural and functional role. Therefore we gave 2-point score in spite of unusual mild phenotype.
RT-PCR using primers that spanned exon 14 showed that the major product from the subject was shorter than in the controls, and sequencing confirmed the deletion of exon 14.

evidence.rdfs:label: Ostrowski LE_UNC78
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: nasal nitric oxide (nNO) levels of 188 and 205 nL/min, above the PCD specific value of < 77 nL/min

evidence.dc:description: A conserved haplotype lies in cis with the c.742G>A mutation, compatible with being a founder mutation. We already scored the Volendam proband homozygous for the c.742G>A mutation PMID 23261303.

The exonic splice-site mutation c.742G>A  yielded two mutant transcripts,
both resulting in premature translation termination signals (Table 2, Figure S2). Using a different downstream primer set revealed another splicing defect on the same mutant allele, indicating impairment of splicing distal to the mutation, (Table 2, Figure S3). The aberrant splicing that is three exons downstream from c.742G>A could not compensate for the upstream frameshift, as the upstream insertions lead to termination codons before the inclusion of intron 10.

RNA analysis indicates that this missense change induces altered splicing that result in a disrupted protein product. The variant is paternally segregated and detected in trans with a previously reported pathogenic variant. Proband has a classical PCD phenotype (otitis media, reduced n(NO) and neonatal RDS) with ultrastructural ODA defect. The variant is detected in homozygosity in a proband with a mild PCD phenotype and residual ciliary activity  PMID: 35163670

The intron 12 splice mutation (c.1391+5G>A ) caused an out-of-frame deletion of exon 12 and a premature translation termination signal. Wild-type amplification product: 479 bp.
Mutant amplification product: 381 bp.

evidence.detectionMethod: mutations in the two genes (DNAH5 [MIM 603335]; DNAI1 [MIM 604366]) most frequently associated with ODA defects  had been excluded by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Situs solitus, ODA ciliary ultrastructural defect

evidence.dc:description:
c.487−2A>G is an intronic splice mutation confirmed by RT-PCR to result in mutant transcripts due to either premature termination signal or deletion of exon 6. Max MAF in Latino/Admixed Americans is 0.00004051. The variant is classified as class 5 in VarSEAK (Exon skipping,
 Loss of function for authentic Splice Site). Patient has manifestations of PCD with ODA defects.

The c.487-2A>G (g.IVS5 2A>G) mutation  yielded two mutant transcripts, one causing premature translation termination signals and another causing in- frame deletion of exon 6 and inclusion of part of intron 6
A conserved haplotype lies in cis with the c.742G>A mutation, compatible with being a founder mutation. We already scored the Volendam proband homozygous for the c.742G>A mutation PMID 23261303.

The exonic splice-site mutation c.742G>A  yielded two mutant transcripts,
both resulting in premature translation termination signals (Table 2, Figure S2). Using a different downstream primer set revealed another splicing defect on the same mutant allele, indicating impairment of splicing distal to the mutation, (Table 2, Figure S3). The aberrant splicing that is three exons downstream from c.742G>A could not compensate for the upstream frameshift, as the upstream insertions lead to termination codons before the inclusion of intron 10.

evidence.detectionMethod: mutations in the two genes (DNAH5 [MIM 603335]; DNAI1 [MIM 604366]) most frequently associated with ODA defects  had been excluded by Sanger sequencing.

family.rdfs:label: PCD-2, PCD-4, PCD-5, PCD6, PCD7, PCD8

evidence.dc:description: This substitution affects the CCDC114 exon 5 consensus splice donor site, predicted to cause a frameshift in the CCDC114 protein product. Highest MAF of 0.00006589 in non-Finnish European population. We downscored for homozygosity.

RT-PCR of the PCD-09 II:1 exon 5 c.486+1G>A UK individual’s sample yielded no product despite repeated attempts to amplify. High-resolution immunofluorescence microscopy in ciliated epithelial cells revealed severely reduced levels of CCDC114 along entire cilia

evidence.rdfs:label: Onoufriadis_PCD-09 II:1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Congenital heart disease, serous otitis media, lobectomy, recurrent bacterial presence, pseudomonas aeruginosa, neonatal dyspnea
